awd_titl_txt: Midbrain Motor Coding of Vocal Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
All classes of motor actions depend on the brain for selecting and sequencing behavior-specific muscle activity patterns. This includes vocalization, a behavior that is shared among fishes, amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals. This remarkable behavior that includes human speech begs the general question: How do brain regions that control movement underlie our ability to select from a menu of available behavioral actions? Vocal behaviors are excellent models for answering this question because they are often highly stereotyped and differ in a small set of easily quantified properties such as frequency, amplitude and duration. There remains an astonishing lack of knowledge of how different brain regions participate in the performance of vocal behavior. This is especially the case for the midbrain that provides a key link between the cerebral hemispheres and central pattern generators found in the hindbrain and spinal cord that directly instruct the activity of muscles. Sound producing fish are champions in the ability to generate vocalizations that exhibit rapid, precisely timed sound pulses. They also provide highly tractable models for studying how the midbrain controls vocal behavior due to a well-characterized and experimentally accessible vocal central pattern generator. The project will investigate the role of the midbrain in the selection, sequencing and/or patterning of different vocal motor behaviors. The Principal Investigator will continue to recruit a talented population of students from diverse backgrounds, including under-represented minorities, and train them in problem-solving at behavioral, neural and molecular levels of analysis.

A practical way to address questions of how vocal motor systems function is to identify model systems, such as those in fish, where behavior is controlled by readily accessible brain centers that share evolutionary and developmental origins with centers in other vertebrates. This project has two aims that will use behavioral, neurophysiological and molecular methods to provide the first comprehensive analysis of how the midbrain of a highly species of vocal fish contributes to vocal motor coding and action selection. Aim 1 will map specific midbrain populations activated during different vocalizations by using immunohistochemistry to detect immediate early gene (IEG) expression, a proxy for increased neural activity, in brains collected from vocalizing fish. Aim 1 will also characterize the neurochemical signature of IEG-identified neurons by investigating co-expression with excitatory and inhibitory transmitters and select neuromodulators that are known to modulate midbrain-dependent mechanisms of vocalization.  Aim 2 will then investigate the role of midbrain neuronal populations identified in Aim 1 in the selection, sequencing and/or patterning of vocal behavior by combining neurophysiology, including single neuron recording, with pharmacology to induce and modulate vocal motor activity. The results will inform us about vocal mechanisms and, more broadly, motor behaviors among all groups of vertebrates.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit  

All classes of motor actions depend on the brain for selecting and sequencing behavior-specific muscle activity patterns. How do brain regions that control motor behaviors such as locomotion or vocalization select between available patterns, and then sequence these into actions appropriate to an environmental challenge? There remains an astonishing lack of knowledge of how the brain organizes vocalizations. A practical way to address questions of vocal control is to identify model systems, such as those in fish, where behavior is controlled by readily accessible brain centers that share evolutionary and developmental origins with centers in birds and mammals, including primates. The completion of this project represents the first comprehensive analysis of how the midbrain of non-mammals contributes to vocal motor coding and action selection and, more broadly, the performance of motor behaviors. There were two overarching projects.

(1) Social context-specific vocalization. How the brain selects between vocalizations specific to social context remains largely unexplored. Such a mechanism was identified within the midbrain periaqueductal gray (PAG) of a highly vocal fish. Behavioral studies of calling males were combined with molecular characterization of neurons active during vocalization, and computational comparisons between the neurophysiological output of the vocal neuron network and natural call features. Many PAG neurons are active during one call type or during both courtship and agonistic calling, with few co-activated during a non-vocal behavior. Pharmacological manipulations within the PAG induced vocal network activity matching the temporal features of courtship and agonistic calls. These findings are the strongest evidence to date, and for the first time in a non-mammal, that the midbrain PAG plays an active role in the selection of vocalizations appropriate to divergent social contexts.

(2) A new neuro-genomic model for social-acoustic communication. A new vertebrate model for behavioral and neural studies of vocal-acoustic communication was developed for a species within the genus Danionella, a group of miniature fish closely related to zebrafish that are transparent throughout their life, into adulthood. The first comprehensive study of the social behavior of any species within this genus was completed that provides a platform for investigating neural mechanisms of social interactions. The results showed that only male Danionella dracula produce bursts of sound pulses along with a distinct postural display, extension of a hypertrophied lower jaw, during aggressive but not courtship interactions. These studies provide the foundation for investigating the role of the brain in controlling multimodal displays in a new model system for aggressive behaviors.

The small size of Danionella adults (about 1.7 cm) together with their transparency also offers an unprecedented opportunity for non-invasive probing of the brain using optical imaging. Multiphoton microscopy demonstrated in vivo mapping of large fractions of the brain and characterization of changes in the volume of sensory-related integration brain regions over the course of development into adulthood. Complete optical access in all life stages of Danionella opens the door for investigating correlated changes in vertebrate brain structure and behavior throughout early life into adulthood.

 

Broader Impact

The Principal Investigator (PI) recruited and trained a diverse population of nine undergraduates (including 8 women), two graduate students (including one women), a postdoctoral associate, and a research associate (woman) in behavioral, neural, and molecular methods of scientific investigation, inclusive of critical thinking and problem-solving skills that will be valuable in the pursuit of any profession they choose to follow. All these individuals were essential members of research collaborations that led to the above reported scientific findings.  

     During the COVID pandemic when campus laboratories were closed to undergraduates, the PI and graduate students maintained the engagement of a team of undergraduate students in a behavioral research project via Zoom conferencing.

The PI and other lab members also:

(1) presented scientific findings at local, national, and international conferences, and in high visibility, peer-reviewed journals; undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral and research associates were included as co-authors on peer-reviewed publications,

(2) participated in Cornell University outreach program for graduate students (GRASHOPR) that helps formulate lesson plans for local elementary schools,

(3) participated in undergraduate research forums sponsored by the Cornell Undergraduate Research Board (CURB) and mentored undergraduates in resume preparation,

(4) provided an interactive exhibit of vertebrate brains in a yearly biology awareness event led by the PI?s home department,

(5) collaborated with PIs at other institutions to maintain a public exhibit about sound producing fish at the University of California Bodega Marine Laboratory,

(6) provided photographs for children books, textbooks and websites, and interviews reporting the lab?s studies, including Peculiar Planet: The Podcast, Swedish Public Service Television, Auditory Language Group? University of Geneva, Popular Science magazine, BYU Radio, The Guardian, ScienceAlert, The Atlantic, popular science book by James Liao (University of Florida),

(7) supplied videos of acoustic communication in fish for Swedish Public Service Television; Auditory Language Group at the University of Geneva; Popular Science magazine; Expertscape.
